sentences.text: So hello everyone, I am Vik Shant, so today we will be learning about OOPs, Object-oriented programming.

We will take a real simple example of a coffee machine and we will see. So think of the coffee machine as a class, it is like a blueprint, it defines the functions of a coffee machine like making a coffee, making a cappuccino, a latte, etc.
Now, when you buy a real coffee machine, it is like an object, right?
It is by it and placed on a table, like an object. Now let us come to the OOPs part of it.

improvement.reason: The phrase 'It is by it' is grammatically incorrect and unclear, making the sentence confusing.
improvement.suggestion: When you actually buy and place a physical coffee machine on a table, that's like creating an object, an instance of our coffee machine class. Now let's dive into the core concepts of OOP.

sentences.text: The OOPs has four different pillars, the first one is encapsulation.
Now, what is the capsule, it is the capsule, right? What is the capsule, it has a medicine inside and it is hidden by the outer capsule.

improvement.reason: The explanation is repetitive and slightly confusing, not directly linking the 'capsule' to the concept of encapsulation clearly.
improvement.suggestion: Think of a medicine capsule: it contains the medicine inside, and that internal medicine is hidden and protected by the outer shell of the capsule.

sentences.text: Now, in terms of the coffee machine, a coffee machine has some internal wiring, it has a heating element, it has a coffee grinder, it is all hidden under the outer casing.
Now, this is encapsulation like bundling of data and hiding under the casing.

improvement.reason: The definition of encapsulation is incomplete, missing the bundling of methods and the purpose of data hiding in programming.
improvement.suggestion: In programming, encapsulation is similar: it's the bundling of data (like the coffee machine's internal state) and the methods that operate on that data (like making coffee) into a single unit, while also restricting direct access to some of the component's internal details, which is known as data hiding.

sentences.text: Now, moving on to the next one, it is abstraction. Now, it may seem like a big term, but it really isn't.
Now, suppose I want to express it. Now, how do you say to the machine, like I just press a button off, I express it and it gives me an express.

improvement.reason: The term 'express' is used repeatedly, likely a mispronunciation of 'espresso,' making the sentence unclear.
improvement.suggestion: Suppose I want an espresso. How do I tell the machine? I simply press a button labeled 'Espresso', and it delivers the drink.

sentences.text: I don't care about the steps to make an express, right? That is handled by the machine.

improvement.reason: Continues the mispronunciation of 'espresso,' which hinders understanding.
improvement.suggestion: I don't need to know the complex internal steps the machine takes to make an espresso; those details are handled internally by the machine.

sentences.text: So, it is, the machine is abstracting the function to make an express and simply giving me a button.

improvement.reason: Continues the mispronunciation of 'espresso' and the phrasing could be more precise about what abstraction means in this context.
improvement.suggestion: So, the machine is abstracting away the complex process of making an espresso, presenting only a simple interface—a button—for me to use.

sentences.text: That is abstraction. Moving on to the next one, it is inheritance.
Now, inheritance is really simple, it is like you inherit your father's property, right?
Now, in terms of the coffee machine, like suppose you have a smaller coffee machine and then your budget increases and you buy a premium one.
Now, suppose the smaller one only makes espresso and heats up water.
And the premium one, it makes tapuccino, it makes elate and also makes, it definitely makes an espresso and heats up water, right?

improvement.reason: Contains mispronunciations ('tapuccino', 'elate') and is slightly repetitive, affecting clarity.
improvement.suggestion: The premium one, however, can make a cappuccino, a latte, and it definitely still makes an espresso and heats up water.

sentences.text: So, it is inheriting the properties of the base one and also addigates own properties.

improvement.reason: 'addigates' is a grammatical error. 'Properties' could be more specific in a programming context.
improvement.suggestion: So, the premium machine is inheriting the core functionalities of the base model and also adding its own unique features.

sentences.text: Now, think in terms of cars, you have a base version and then you have a higher end model.
Now, obviously the higher end model has all the features of the base one plus some extra features, right?
Now, moving on to the last one, with this fallen morphism. Now, it seems like a complex term, but it is really simple.

improvement.reason: 'fallen morphism' is a clear mispronunciation of 'polymorphism'.
improvement.suggestion: Now, moving on to the last pillar, which is polymorphism. It might sound like a complex term, but its concept is quite simple.

sentences.text: What it simply means is many forms or multiple forms.
Now, suppose I have two coffee machines, one of brand X and one of brand Y.
Now, and I have a same button, brew on both of them. Now, when I press the brew button on the brand X, it makes an espresso.
When I press the same button on brand Y, it makes a filter coffee.
Now, the same function, the same button, performs multiple function, it appears in multiple forms.

improvement.reason: Grammatical error ('multiple function' instead of 'multiple functions') and could benefit from a brief mention of its programming implications.
improvement.suggestion: So, the same function, invoked by the same 'brew' button, performs multiple different actions depending on the specific coffee machine, demonstrating how it appears in multiple forms.

sentences.text: That is polymorphism. That's right, guys. I have my vaccine, everything is fine.

improvement.reason: Contains irrelevant and unprofessional personal commentary that detracts from the lecture.

sentences.text: Thank you so much.
